issues.title: Timing Belt Failure (M20/M42 Engines)
issues.symptoms: Engine won't start, loud slapping noise before failure, visible belt wear or cracking
issues.description: The M20 (6-cylinder) and M42 (4-cylinder) engines in the E30 use timing belts rather than chains. These belts have a service interval of approximately 50,000 miles, but many recommend replacing them earlier. The M20 is an interference engine, meaning if the belt snaps, the pistons will contact the valves causing catastrophic engine damage.
fixes: Replace timing belt every 50,000 miles or 4 years (whichever comes first)
Replace water pump and tensioner at the same time
Inspect and replace idler pulleys if worn
Always replace the front crankshaft seal during service

repairCosts.notes: Critical maintenance. Replace water pump at same time.

issues.title: Rust and Corrosion
issues.symptoms: Bubbling paint, visible rust holes, soft floor pans, rusty fenders and wheel arches
issues.description: E30s are notorious for rust, especially in areas with road salt. Common rust spots include the front fenders (behind the wheels), rear wheel arches, rocker panels, battery tray, and floor pans. The trunk floor and spare tire well are also vulnerable. Rust can compromise structural integrity if left untreated.
fixes: Inspect and treat rust early - surface rust is much easier to fix
Replace fenders if rust is beyond repair (aftermarket available)
Weld in new metal for floor pan and structural rust
Apply rust prevention (POR-15, Fluid Film) to undercarriage
Keep drain holes clear to prevent water accumulation

repairCosts.notes: Cost varies widely by extent. Fenders and floors most common.

issues.title: Electrical Gremlins
issues.symptoms: Intermittent gauge failures, flickering lights, dead pixels in OBC, non-working windows/sunroof
issues.description: The E30's electrical system, while simpler than modern BMWs, suffers from age-related issues. Ground points corrode, causing erratic behavior. The instrument cluster capacitors fail, leading to dead gauges or pixels. Window and sunroof switches wear out. The check control panel and on-board computer (OBC) are known failure points.
fixes: Clean and re-ground all chassis ground points
Replace instrument cluster capacitors (common DIY repair)
Rebuild or replace OBC units
Check and clean all fuse box connections
Replace worn window/sunroof switches

repairCosts.notes: Often ground connection issues. Check grounds first.

issues.title: Suspension Bushing Wear
issues.symptoms: Clunking over bumps, vague steering, uneven tire wear, wandering at highway speeds
issues.description: After 30+ years, nearly all E30s have worn suspension bushings. The front control arm bushings, subframe mounts, rear trailing arm bushings, and sway bar end links all deteriorate with age. Worn bushings dramatically affect handling and can accelerate wear on other suspension components.
fixes: Full suspension refresh with new bushings (OEM rubber or polyurethane)
Replace control arms with fresh bushings
Install new subframe mounts
Replace rear trailing arm bushings (notorious for wear)
Don't forget sway bar bushings and end links

repairCosts.notes: Full refresh transforms handling. Common on 30+ year old cars.

issues.title: Fuel Injection Issues (Bosch Motronic)
issues.symptoms: Hard starting, rough idle, poor fuel economy, hesitation under acceleration, stalling
issues.description: E30s use Bosch Motronic or L-Jetronic fuel injection systems. Common failure points include the idle control valve (ICV), mass airflow sensor (AFM), coolant temperature sensor, and fuel injectors. Vacuum leaks from aged hoses also cause running issues. The fuel pump and filter should be checked if fuel delivery is suspected.
fixes: Clean or replace the idle control valve (ICV)
Test and replace AFM (airflow meter) if faulty
Replace all vacuum hoses with new silicone lines
Replace coolant temperature sensor
Clean injectors or replace with new/rebuilt units
Replace fuel filter and check fuel pump pressure

repairCosts.notes: Motronic systems need proper diagnosis. AFM common failure.

issues.title: Cooling System Failures
issues.symptoms: Overheating, coolant leaks, heater not working, temperature gauge fluctuation
issues.description: While more robust than later BMW cooling systems, the E30's cooling components still fail with age. The water pump, thermostat, and radiator are common failure points. The heater core is known to leak, and the expansion tank can crack. On M20 engines, the head gasket can fail if overheating occurs.
fixes: Replace water pump (do with timing belt service)
Install new thermostat (80°C or 88°C based on preference)
Replace radiator if original (plastic end tanks crack)
Flush system and use BMW-approved coolant
Replace heater core if leaking (labor-intensive job)

repairCosts.notes: Replace all hoses and thermostat during water pump service.

guides.title: Full Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Complete front and rear suspension overhaul including all bushings, shocks, struts, and steering components. Restores factory handling and eliminates clunks, wandering, and uneven tire wear.
tools: Ball joint separator or pickle fork
Bushing press kit or hydraulic press
Floor jack and jack stands (4 minimum)
steps: Raise the vehicle and secure on four jack stands. Remove all four wheels.
FRONT SUSPENSION: Remove the brake caliper (13mm bolts) and hang with wire - do not let it hang by the hose.
Remove the tie rod end nut (19mm) and separate using a ball joint separator. Count threads visible for alignment reference.
Remove the sway bar end link nuts (16mm) from the strut.
Remove the pinch bolt (16mm) holding the strut to the steering knuckle.
Remove the three 13mm nuts from the strut tower in the engine bay.
Lower the strut assembly out of the wheel well.
Use a spring compressor to safely compress the spring, then remove the 22mm strut nut.
Replace the strut insert, bump stop, dust boot, and strut mount. Torque strut nut to 47 ft-lbs.
Reinstall strut assembly - torque strut tower nuts to 16 ft-lbs, pinch bolt to 59 ft-lbs.
For control arm bushings: Remove the control arm (19mm bolts) and press out old bushings.
Press in new bushings using a bushing press or vise with appropriate receivers.
Reinstall control arm - torque to 57 ft-lbs. Note: Final torque at ride height.
REAR SUSPENSION: Remove the rear shock lower bolt (19mm) and upper nuts (13mm) in trunk.
Install new shocks - torque upper nuts to 16 ft-lbs, lower bolt to 57 ft-lbs.
For trailing arm bushings: Support the trailing arm and remove the pivot bolt (19mm).
Press out old bushings and press in new ones. Reinstall bolt and torque to 52 ft-lbs at ride height.
Replace subframe bushings by supporting the subframe, removing bolts, and pressing in new bushings.
Replace sway bar bushings and end links on both axles.
Reinstall wheels, lower vehicle, and torque lug nuts to 80 ft-lbs.
CRITICAL: Get a four-wheel alignment within 50 miles. Do not final-torque suspension bolts until at ride height.
tips: Spray all bolts with penetrating oil 24 hours before starting to ease removal.
Take photos of the suspension geometry before disassembly for reference.
Lemforder and Meyle HD bushings are OEM-equivalent quality - avoid cheap alternatives.
Bilstein B6 (yellow) offers improved damping over stock without being too stiff for street use.
If the strut tower nuts are seized, use heat carefully - the tower is thin metal.
Powerflex polyurethane bushings last longer but transmit more NVH than rubber.
warnings: Spring compressors are extremely dangerous if used incorrectly - follow all safety procedures.
Never work under a vehicle supported only by a jack - always use jack stands.
Suspension bolts must be final-torqued with the weight of the car on the wheels (ride height).
Worn strut mounts can cause clunking and affect handling - always inspect and replace if worn.

guides.title: Rust Repair & Prevention
guides.description: E30-specific rust identification and repair guide. Covers the common rot spots including front fenders, rocker panels, rear wheel arches, and floor pans with techniques for cutting, welding, and long-term prevention.
tools: Angle grinder with cut-off wheels and flap discs
Safety equipment: auto-darkening helmet, gloves, fire extinguisher
steps: ASSESSMENT: Remove interior carpets, spare tire, and trunk liner to inspect floor pans.
Remove front fender liners and inspect the inner fender and frame rails.
Check common E30 rust areas: front fenders behind side markers, rocker panels at jacking points, rear wheel arches, battery tray, trunk floor.
Use a screwdriver to probe suspect areas - solid metal won't flex or puncture.
Mark all areas requiring repair and photograph for reference.
PREPARATION: Remove all paint and underseal around repair areas using a grinder with flap disc.
Grind or sandblast back to clean metal, extending 2-3 inches beyond the rust.
Treat any remaining surface rust with rust converter and allow to cure (24 hours).
For structural panels (floor, frame rails), support the body before cutting.
CUTTING: Use a spot weld drill to remove factory spot welds where possible - preserves surrounding metal.
For patch panels, cut along the factory seam lines using cut-off wheel or plasma cutter.
Cut 1 inch into good metal to ensure full rust removal.
FABRICATION: Test-fit patch panels and trim as needed for proper fit.
Create butt joints or lap joints depending on location and access.
Drill holes for plug welds if replacing spot welds.
WELDING: Apply weld-through primer to all bare metal surfaces.
Use Cleco fasteners to hold panels in position for tack welding.
Tack weld every 2-3 inches, then fill in with short stitch welds to prevent warping.
Allow metal to cool between welds - touch test with back of hand.
Grind welds smooth with flap disc.
SEALING: Apply seam sealer to all welded joints inside and out.
Coat repair area with POR-15 or epoxy primer for rust prevention.
Apply cavity wax inside all boxed sections through drain holes.
Reinstall trim, undercoating, and paint as needed.
tips: Klokkerholm panels from Europe are the best quality reproduction panels available.
Remove the gas tank before any welding near the rear of the car.
Use a heat sink (wet rag or copper backing) to prevent warping thin panels.
Stitch welding in 1-inch segments with cooling time prevents heat distortion.
POR-15 must be applied over rust-free metal or rust converter for best results.
Cavity wax through factory drain holes protects inside of rockers and frame rails.
If the subframe mounting points are rusty, do not drive the car - this is a safety issue.
warnings: Welding near fuel lines or the gas tank can cause fire or explosion - disconnect battery and remove fuel.
Structural rust in frame rails or subframe mounts requires professional assessment before repair.
Cutting into structural panels without proper support can cause body flex and misalignment.
Always have a fire extinguisher within reach when welding on a vehicle.
Wear proper respiratory protection when grinding rust - it can contain lead from old paint.

guides.title: Electrical System Restoration
guides.description: Comprehensive guide to diagnosing and restoring the E30's electrical system. Covers ground point restoration, relay replacement, fuse box rebuild, and common wiring repairs for reliable operation.
steps: GROUND POINTS: Disconnect the battery negative terminal before starting any electrical work.
Locate the main ground points: engine to chassis (front left), battery to body (inner fender), and transmission to body.
Remove each ground strap and inspect - look for corrosion, frayed wires, or loose connections.
Clean mounting surfaces with wire brush until shiny bare metal.
Apply dielectric grease to prevent future corrosion, reinstall straps and torque securely.
The hidden ground behind the glovebox is critical - remove the glovebox to access and clean.
FUSE BOX: Remove the fuse box cover and inspect all fuses with a test light.
A fuse can look good but have an internal break - test with power applied.
Clean fuse contacts with electrical contact cleaner and a small brush.
Inspect the fusible links on the main power distribution - these are common failure points.
If the fuse box shows heat damage or melted plastic, rebuild or replace it.
RELAY TESTING: The E30 uses several critical relays - DME/fuel pump, headlights, turn signals, horn.
Test relays by swapping with known-good units or testing with multimeter.
The DME relay (under the hood, driver side) is the most common failure - replace preventatively.
Clean relay socket contacts with electrical contact cleaner.
WIRING REPAIRS: Inspect the engine harness for cracked insulation, especially near the exhaust.
Check the trunk wiring where it passes through the body - flex point causes breaks.
Repair damaged wires with proper splicing - solder and heat shrink, not just electrical tape.
The headlight wiring can melt from undersized stock wires - upgrade to heavier gauge if dim headlights.
INSTRUMENT CLUSTER: Remove the cluster and replace burned-out bulbs.
Clean the printed circuit board contacts with contact cleaner.
Check the odometer gears - broken gears are common and cause non-functioning odometer.
tips: The DME relay is the most common cause of no-start conditions - always keep a spare.
When testing for voltage drops, 0.1V or less is acceptable on ground circuits.
Dielectric grease on connections prevents corrosion without affecting conductivity.
Consider upgrading to a relay-controlled headlight harness for significantly brighter lights.
The C101 connector (behind the glovebox) is notorious for intermittent connections.
Wrap repaired wiring with split loom tubing to protect from heat and abrasion.
warnings: Always disconnect the battery before working on electrical systems.
Shorts can cause immediate fire - never bypass fuses or use higher-rated fuses than specified.
The fusible links protect against major shorts - if they blow repeatedly, find the root cause.
Aftermarket stereo installations are often done poorly and cause electrical issues.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Complete interior restoration guide for the E30 including seat reupholstery, dashboard repair, carpet replacement, and headliner restoration. Return your interior to factory-fresh condition.
tools: Hog ring pliers and hog rings
steps: SEATS: Remove seats from vehicle - four 13mm bolts per seat, disconnect heated seat wiring if equipped.
Remove the seat covers by unclipping hog rings from the seat frame with pliers.
Inspect seat foam - collapsed or cracked foam should be replaced.
If recovering, use the old covers as templates for new material.
Install new foam, then stretch new covers over and secure with new hog rings.
For leather care only: clean with dedicated leather cleaner, then condition and protect.
CARPET: Remove seats, door sill plates, center console, and kick panels.
Pull up old carpet and inspect floor for rust - repair any rust before installing new carpet.
Clean and treat floor with sound deadening if desired.
Test-fit new molded carpet and trim where needed for pedals and transmission tunnel.
Secure carpet with adhesive at edges and under door sills.
HEADLINER: This is the most challenging interior repair - work carefully.
Remove all trim around the edges: sun visors, dome light, A/B/C pillar trim.
Carefully lower the headliner board through the door opening.
Remove old fabric and all foam backing - scrape and wire brush until smooth.
Apply spray adhesive to both the board and new fabric, wait until tacky.
Starting from the center, press fabric onto board working outward to edges.
Wrap fabric around edges and trim excess. Cut holes for dome light and visors.
Allow to cure 24 hours before reinstalling in the vehicle.
DASHBOARD: For cracks, clean the area thoroughly and fill with flexible filler.
Sand smooth, apply texture coat to match, then paint with interior dye.
Alternatively, install a dash cap cover for a quick solution.
Clean and condition all vinyl and plastic trim with appropriate products.
tips: Work in a temperature-controlled environment - adhesives don't work well in cold or extreme heat.
Original E30 leather is very durable - often just needs thorough cleaning and conditioning.
Lseat.com offers excellent pattern-matched E30 seat covers at reasonable prices.
The headliner board is fragile - handle with care and don't bend it sharply.
Use 3M Super 90 for headliner work - it's stronger than Super 77.
Taking photos before disassembly helps with reassembly of trim pieces.
Condor Speed Shop offers complete interior restoration kits for E30s.
warnings: Spray adhesive should only be used in well-ventilated areas - fumes are harmful.
The headliner board can break if flexed too much - remove carefully through the door.
Leather dye is permanent - test on a hidden area first.
Heated seats have electrical connections that can short if damaged - disconnect battery first.

engine.notes: Torque-to-yield, replace each use. Wait 15 min between stages.

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete guide to changing oil and filter on M20 and M42 engines. Regular oil changes are the single most important maintenance item for engine longevity.
steps: Warm up the engine for 5 minutes to thin the oil, then turn off and let sit for 2 minutes.
Lift the front of the car and secure on jack stands. Never work under a car supported only by a jack.
Position drain pan under the oil pan. The drain plug is located at the rear of the oil pan.
Remove the 17mm drain plug and allow oil to drain completely (10-15 minutes).
While draining, remove the oil filter using an oil filter wrench. The filter is located on the driver's side of the engine block.
Apply a thin layer of fresh oil to the new filter gasket. Hand-tighten the new filter until the gasket contacts, then turn an additional 3/4 turn.
Clean the drain plug and inspect the crush washer. Replace the washer if it's damaged or reused multiple times.
Reinstall the drain plug and torque to 18-22 ft-lbs (25-30 Nm).
Lower the car and add oil through the filler cap. M20: 5.0 quarts, M42: 4.5 quarts.
Start the engine and check for leaks. Let idle for 2 minutes, then turn off and check the oil level. Top off as needed.
tips: Use 15W-40 or 20W-50 for high-mileage engines, 10W-40 for normal use
Always use a quality filter - Mann, Mahle, or OEM BMW
Check for oil leaks from the valve cover gasket while you're under the car

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement with rotor inspection. Essential safety maintenance that should not be delayed when pads are worn.
diyGuides.interval: Every 25,000-50,000 miles or when pad thickness reaches 3mm
tools: Large C-clamp or brake piston tool
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground. Lift the car and secure on jack stands.
Remove the wheel to access the brake caliper.
Remove the two 7mm hex bolts holding the caliper carrier to the caliper bracket.
Slide the caliper off the rotor. Do not let it hang by the brake line - support it with a wire or bungee.
Remove the old brake pads from the caliper carrier. Note the orientation of any wear sensors.
Inspect the rotor surface for scoring, hot spots, or excessive wear. Minimum thickness is stamped on the rotor.
Use a C-clamp to compress the caliper piston back into the caliper body. Open the brake fluid reservoir cap first to prevent pressure buildup.
Clean the caliper slides and apply fresh brake grease. Inspect the slide pin boots for tears.
Install the new pads into the carrier. The pad with the wear sensor (if equipped) goes on the inner position.
Reinstall the caliper over the new pads and torque the slide bolts to 22-26 ft-lbs.
Reinstall the wheel and torque lug bolts to 80 ft-lbs in a star pattern.
Before driving, pump the brake pedal several times until firm to seat the pads against the rotors.
tips: Bed in new pads: 10 moderate stops from 30 mph, then 10 harder stops from 40 mph
Replace pads in axle pairs - both fronts or both rears together
Check brake fluid level after compressing pistons - it will rise in the reservoir

diyGuides.title: Timing Belt Replacement
diyGuides.description: Step-by-step timing belt, tensioner, and water pump replacement. Critical service for M20 and M42 engines - failure causes catastrophic valve damage.
diyGuides.interval: Every 50,000 miles or 4 years (whichever comes first)
diyGuides.cost: $150-250 for parts (belt, tensioner, water pump, seals)
steps: Drain coolant from the radiator using the petcock at the bottom. Collect in a clean pan if reusing.
Remove the fan shroud (4 clips) and fan clutch (32mm, turns clockwise to loosen - reverse thread).
Remove the accessory belts by loosening the tensioner pulleys.
Remove the upper and lower timing belt covers (10mm bolts).

Rotate the engine clockwise using a 22mm socket on the crank bolt until the timing marks align. The cam gear dot should point straight up, and the crank gear dot should align with the mark on the oil pump housing.
Insert a 6mm pin or drill bit through the hole in the flywheel (access from below) to lock the engine at TDC.
Loosen the timing belt tensioner and remove the old belt. Note the direction of rotation marked on the belt.
Remove the water pump (6 bolts). Clean the mating surface thoroughly.
Install the new water pump with a new gasket. Torque bolts to 7 ft-lbs in a cross pattern.
Install the new timing belt starting at the crank gear. Keep tension on the belt between the crank and cam gears.
Set belt tension by rotating the tensioner until the belt can be twisted 90 degrees with moderate finger pressure.
Rotate the engine two full revolutions by hand and verify timing marks still align. If not, repeat the process.
Reinstall timing covers, fan, belts, and refill coolant. Run engine and check for leaks.
tips: Never reuse an old timing belt - always replace when removed
Replace the front crank seal and cam seal while the covers are off
Use only OEM or high-quality belts (Continental, Gates) - not cheap alternatives
Mark the old belt's rotation direction - running a used belt backward can cause failure

diyGuides.title: Cooling System Service
diyGuides.description: Complete coolant flush and thermostat replacement. Prevents overheating failures that can destroy the head gasket or warp the cylinder head.
tools: Flush kit or garden hose adapter
steps: Allow the engine to cool completely. Never open the cooling system when hot.
Place a drain pan under the radiator and open the petcock at the bottom of the radiator. Also open the bleed screw on the thermostat housing to speed draining.
Remove the lower radiator hose for more complete drainage. Approximately 2 gallons will drain.
For a thorough flush: close the petcock, fill with distilled water, run the engine to operating temp with heat on high, drain again. Repeat until water runs clear.
Remove the thermostat housing (upper radiator hose neck). The M20 housing uses 10mm bolts.
Remove the old thermostat. Note the orientation - the spring goes toward the engine.
Clean the mating surfaces of all old gasket material. Do not let debris fall into the engine.
Install the new thermostat with a new gasket. Use an 88°C (192°F) thermostat for normal driving, 80°C (176°F) for warm climates or track use.
Reinstall the housing and hoses. Torque bolts to 7 ft-lbs. Do not overtighten - the housing is aluminum.
Fill the system with a 50/50 mix of BMW-approved coolant and distilled water. Fill slowly to minimize air pockets.
Leave the bleed screw open until a steady stream of coolant (no bubbles) emerges, then close it.
Start the engine with the heat on high. Watch the temperature gauge and top off coolant as air bleeds out. The level will drop as air pockets clear.
tips: Use BMW blue coolant or a phosphate-free equivalent - never use green universal coolant
Replace the expansion tank if it shows any cracks or discoloration
Squeeze the upper hose while filling to help push air out of the system

engine.name: Rebuild/replace AFM (Air Flow Meter)
engine.description: Common failure point on M20 engines

engine.name: Inspect oil cooler lines
engine.description: M20 engines - check for leaks at banjo fittings

suspension.name: Replace rear trailing arm bushings
suspension.description: Critical for handling and tire wear

suspension.name: Inspect front subframe mounts
suspension.description: Check for cracks in mounting points

buyersGuide.overview: The BMW E30 3 Series (1982-1994) represents the golden era of BMW engineering - a time when the company built driver-focused cars with exceptional balance, communicative steering, and an analog driving experience that modern BMWs struggle to replicate. The E30 was the car that established BMW's reputation in North America and remains one of the most sought-after classic BMWs. Whether you want a practical classic daily driver, a weekend canyon carver, or a track day weapon, the E30 delivers. However, these cars are now 30-40+ years old, and rust, deferred maintenance, and questionable modifications are common. A thorough pre-purchase inspection is essential.

variants.name: 325i / 325is
variants.description: The sweet spot of the E30 range. The 2.5L M20B25 engine produces 168 hp and offers the best balance of performance, reliability, and parts availability. The 'is' denotes the sport package with limited-slip differential, sport seats, and firmer suspension.

variants.name: 325e / 325es
variants.description: The 'eta' engine prioritizes fuel economy with a 2.7L low-revving motor producing 121 hp. Great for relaxed cruising but lacks the sporting character of the 'i' models. Can be converted to 'i' spec.

variants.name: 318i / 318is
variants.description: Entry-level E30 with the M10 (early) or M42 (1991) four-cylinder. The 1991 318is with the M42 is particularly desirable - rev-happy engine in the lightest E30 chassis. Earlier M10 cars are basic but charming.

variants.name: M3
variants.description: The legendary homologation special with the S14 2.3L four-cylinder producing 192 hp. Wider fenders, aggressive aerodynamics, and motorsport DNA. Values have skyrocketed - expect $50,000-$150,000+ for clean examples.

variants.name: 325ix
variants.description: All-wheel-drive variant with a sophisticated viscous-coupling system. Great for snowy climates but adds complexity and weight. Unique drivetrain components can be expensive to repair.

variants.name: Convertible
variants.description: Open-top E30 built by Baur (early) or fully by BMW (later). Heavier and less rigid than coupes/sedans but offers top-down driving enjoyment. Check carefully for rust and top mechanism issues.

items.detail: Peel back the fender liner and inspect with a flashlight. Look for bubbling, flaking, or holes. This is the #1 rust area on E30s.
Jack up the car and inspect the pinch welds and rocker panels. Poke with a screwdriver - solid metal won't flex. Check under side skirts if equipped.
Common rust area, especially on sedans. Check both inside the trunk and outside the quarter panels.
In the trunk, inspect the battery tray and surrounding area. Battery acid accelerates rust here. Check floor underneath.
Pull back the carpets and check the driver and passenger floor pans. Look for rust-through or patched areas.
Critical structural area. Any rust here is a safety issue. Check both front and rear subframe mounts.
M20 and M42 engines use timing belts that must be replaced every 50,000 miles. Ask for records - if unknown, budget for immediate replacement.
Look for coolant in the oil (milky residue on dipstick/oil cap) or oil in coolant. Check for overheating history. M20s are known for head gasket failures.
Inspect valve cover gasket, oil pan gasket, rear main seal, and front crank seal. Some seepage is normal on older cars, but active drips indicate needed repairs.
Test the clutch engagement point - should be smooth and grab in the middle of pedal travel. Slipping under load indicates worn clutch.
Test all gears, especially 2nd gear. Grinding or difficulty engaging indicates worn synchros. Getrag 260 transmissions are robust but not indestructible.
Jack up the front end and check for play in the control arms. Worn bushings cause clunking and vague steering.
The most commonly worn rear suspension component. Causes diagonal tire wear and poor handling. Check for cracking or deformation.
Check for play in the steering wheel with the car stationary. Listen for clunks when turning lock-to-lock. Inspect boots for tears.
Bad strut mounts cause clunking over bumps and wandering steering. Bounce each corner and listen for noises.
E30 electrical gremlins are often traced to corroded grounds. Check that all accessories work - windows, sunroof, gauges, lights.
Look for dead pixels, non-working gauges, or flickering lights. Capacitor failure is common and affects multiple gauges.
Plastic odometer gears commonly break. A non-working odometer makes true mileage unverifiable.
Check for coolant stains, cracked plastic end tanks, or bent fins. Original radiators are often 30+ years old.
Look underneath the water pump for coolant residue. A weeping pump is about to fail.
Check for wet carpet on the passenger side or sweet coolant smell inside. Heater core replacement is labor-intensive.

project.description: Non-running or heavily rusted cars needing major work. Only for experienced builders with welding skills. Budget 2-3x purchase price for restoration.

driver.description: Running and driving with some issues - cosmetic flaws, minor rust, deferred maintenance. Can be enjoyed while improving over time.

excellent.description: Well-maintained examples with documented history, minimal rust, good cosmetics. May have tasteful modifications or be mostly stock.

concours.description: Museum-quality cars, often M3s or rare variants. Fully documented, low miles, completely original or professionally restored.

redFlags: Structural rust in subframe mounting points, shock towers, or frame rails - walk away or budget for professional restoration
Unknown timing belt service history on M20/M42 engines - assume it needs immediate replacement
Signs of previous flood damage - musty interior smell, water lines in trunk, corroded electrical connectors
Salvage or rebuilt title without clear explanation of the damage
Excessive modifications with poor workmanship - cut wiring, mismatched parts, amateur body work
Seller unwilling to allow pre-purchase inspection by an independent mechanic
Oil in coolant or coolant in oil - indicates head gasket failure or worse
M3 cars without proper documentation or with suspiciously low prices
whatToLookFor: Documented service history, especially timing belt records
Limited-slip differential (standard on 'is' models, optional on others)
Sport seats with manual adjustment and better bolstering
Factory air conditioning (works well when properly maintained)
Original tool kit and first aid kit in trunk
Matching VIN tags on body panels (indicates no accident repair)
Original paint in good condition (single-stage paint holds up well)
Rust-free California, Arizona, or southern cars
Factory options like heated seats, on-board computer, or cruise control
expertTips: Join R3VLimited.com before buying - the community can help verify cars and identify red flags
Budget for a full suspension refresh on any E30 - bushings wear out and transform the driving experience when replaced
The 'is' package (325is, 318is) adds significant value - limited-slip diff and sport suspension are expensive to add later
Convertibles rust more due to water intrusion - inspect very carefully around the top mechanism and rear quarters
Early 1984-1986 cars have different bumpers and trim that are harder to find - later facelift parts (1988+) are more available
The M20 engine is extremely robust when maintained - 300,000+ mile examples exist with proper care
Consider a pre-purchase inspection by an E30 specialist - generic mechanics may miss model-specific issues
Beware of 'M3 clone' cars - legitimate conversions are rare and expensive, most are poorly done
Factor in the cost of period-correct replacement parts - many items are discontinued and expensive
An E30 in solid mechanical condition with rust is often a better buy than a rust-free car with a tired drivetrain - metal work is harder than mechanical repairs
